docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 17-- Senators J.W. Fulbright and Wayne Morse split sharply today over the extent to which President Johnson's latest bid for Congressional backing on Latin America would "morally" bind legislators to support future Administration...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 17-- Senators J.W. Fulbright and Wayne Morse split sharply today over the extent to which President Johnson's latest bid for Congressional backing on Latin America would "morally" bind legislators to support future Administration requests.
docs.abstract: Sen Fulbright opposes resolution backing Johnson aid request on grounds Adm could use resolution as 'rubber stamp' for any program, Sen com; backs own substitute resolution urging only 'sympathetic consideration' for any conf aid agreement; Sen Morse disagrees; Sec Rusk comments; HR com approves Adm resolution; Johnson asks 35 Latin-Amer ambs and OAS reprs to Tex ranch for pre-conf visit

headline.main: MORSE DEFENDS STAND ON LATINS; But Fulbright Is Critical of Resolution on Aid

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, March 15-- Not many years ago bandits, big rocks, washed-out bridges, bad food and a lack of places to sleep were the major problems involved in driving the PanAmerican Highway from Mexico to Argentina.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 20 Senator J.W. Fulbright and other members of the influential Foreign Relations Committee were reported today to be bridling over mounting White House pressure on them.

docs.abstract: Fulbright, other Foreign Relations Com members reptd irked by White House pressure to approve resolution; com postpones action; Morse reptdly urges com not give impression of defying Johnson before conf; Johnson reptdly seeks approval before Cong recess

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS N.Y., March 23 Britain lost today a fight to obtain approval in the Special Committee on Colonialism for a grant of limited self-government to six former British West Indian colonies.
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS N.Y., March 23 Britain lost today a fight to obtain approval in the Special Committee on Colonialism for a grant of limited self-government to six former British West Indian colonies.
docs.abstract: UN Colonialism Com, 18-5, refuses to approve Brit grant of ltd self-rule to 6 territories; holds GB did not permit UN observer to be present while territories chose new status and that choice had not been made through referendum; Lord Caradon defends Brit procedures; US backs GB

headline.main: U.N. Unit Rebuffs Britain on Territorial Rule; Refuses to Approve Grant of Limited Self-Government to West Indian Islands
